Award.AwardTitle: Computational-Experimental Insight across Time and Length Scales of Dynamics in Ionic Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The design of new materials is one critical aspect of engineering new platforms that will augment the energy security of the nation, impact health, and enhance economic competitiveness. Driving innovation in technologies such as clean energy generation and storage and numerous biomedical technologies requires new materials that can serve in different capacities simultaneously. One promising class of materials consists of very large molecules (polymers) able to transport ions and electrons while retaining their mechanical integrity, often under extreme conditions of high temperatures, solvents, and external stresses that may affect their performance. The ability of these materials to play multiple roles is attained by tailoring molecular segments with different chemical functionalities into one large molecule, including blocks for transporting ions and electrons and blocks to provide mechanical stability. Controlling the way these segments organize and perform electrically as they are integrated into devices is key to the design of new effective platforms. In this project, using large-scale computational studies coupled with state-of-the-art neutron measurements, the effects of the structure of these polymers will be correlated with their dynamics as they are exposed to high temperatures and solvents. The projected results will provide the understanding that will enhance the ability to design well-controlled multi-functional polymers, tailored with desired properties for specific applications. The project is closely integrated with interdisciplinary education and training of graduate and undergraduate students and high-school outreach.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymers that consist of ionizable blocks (ionomers, or polyelectrolytes) tethered to additional segments with well defined functionalities, constitute promising media for a large number of applications from clean energy and storage to sensors and drug delivery vehicles. The role of the ionic groups is two-fold: they form physical crosslinks while facilitating transport of ions and polar guest molecules. As these two functions often require dynamics of opposing nature, the additional blocks affect the overall stability of such polymers. Here, using large-scale molecular dynamics simulations coupled with neutron scattering techniques, the correlation of polymer dynamics with ionic associations and their cohesiveness will be investigated on a series of model copolymers that consist of styrene sulfonate as the ionic block tethered to different non-ionic segments. Numerous studies have probed the structure of ion-containing polymers and polyelectrolytes, revealing a rich variety of morphologies and establishing a clear correlation between structure and transport. One key challenge that arises from these studies is the need to unfold the correlation between ionic associations and their impact on the mobility of the polymers. The relationship of the dynamics with the number, topology, and stability of the ionic associations impacts the polymer properties and in turn affects a large number of technologies. This research is set to resolve the effects of constraints formed by ionic associations on polymer dynamics. Advances in computational techniques coupled with new developments in neutron scattering will enable a new insight into the dynamics of polymers under the confinement of physical crosslinks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ionic block co-polymers with distinctive block characteristics display the diversity of properties crucial for design of new macromolecules for targeted applications. In these potential technologies such as clean energy, the water nexus, and biotechnology, the polymer has to enable high mobility of ions alongside solvent molecules and at the same time remain highly mechanically stable. One promising path to tailor polymers for specific applications is tethering blocks that exhibit desired properties into one molecule.  Integrating these polymers into devices requires new fundamental understanding of their structure and motion. Here, using advanced computational and experimental tools, the research made significant inroads towards understanding the structure and dynamics of structured ionic polymers in solutions, in melts and across interfaces.  In parallel to the new polymer physics discovered, the effort has contributed to the development of new computational tools, which will enhance the development of materials.

The study focused on one model polymer that consists of blocks that commonly constitute ionizable co-polymers but exhibits a unique arrangement of the blocks where mechanically stabilizing blocks are tethered symmetrically around of an ion-transporting block.  The study showed for the first time that the structure of the polymer is controlled by the kinetics of formation of ionic domains formed by the blocks that drive transport. These kinetic effects supersede the enthalpy-entropy balance that dominates non-ionic polymers that drive mechanical stability. Visualization of such clusters in a polymer melts obtained from computations is presented in the illustration of the polymer melt. The blocks that offer mechanical stability are marked with yellow and orange and the block that offer ionic transport is marked in blue. The ionic groups include an SO3 (yellow for sulfur and red for oxygen) group with a sodium as a counterion.   These ionic clusters are depict as well.   As the ionic clusters are unlocked, the mobility of the polymer increases. These effects were found in solutions as well as in polymer membranes.

In many applications, polymers often reside at an interface with different solids and liquids.  The study showed that the interface of this polymer consists of nano-domains of each of the blocks. These domains respond differently to the presence of solvents in the environment of the polymer. The direct impact of this response lies in new fundamental physics that affects diffusion in polymers. Further, the presence of this domains directly affects the integration of the polymer into different devices.

Finally, in order to control structured polymers with blocks of significantly different nature, the motion of each of the individual blocks has to be fully controlled.  With the new computational model developed, the effects of molecular parameters on the motion of the polymers were investigated focusing on polyethylene. The study investigated how variations in molecular weights and the topography of the polymers affect their motion. The computational model is shown in a separate image together with results of the polymer motion denoted by MSD or mean square displacement. The study finds that small variations in molecular weights of the polymer can increase the motion of the polymers. Similar effects are found when the polymers diverge from linearity.

 Alongside the direct scientific contributions, the educational efforts targeting interdisciplinary educational initiatives were propelled and direct collaboration with a startup company has helped propagate the fundamental knowledge into device development. These research goals are coupled with educational objective to prompt interdisciplinary students? education that encompasses combining computations and neutron scattering tools for the study of polymers.  With the global impact of polymers, the research, and educational efforts, all incorporate fostering international joint scientific efforts.
